OpenSkills: Universal Skills Loader for AI Coding Agents

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

OpenSkills: Universal Skills Loader for AI Coding Agents

Section titled ‚ÄúOpenSkills: Universal Skills Loader for AI Coding Agents‚Äù

AI coding agents have revolutionized software development, but each agent operates in its own ecosystem with unique capabilities. OpenSkills bridges this gap by bringing Anthropic‚Äôs powerful skills system to all AI coding agents.

What is OpenSkills?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is OpenSkills?‚Äù

OpenSkills is a universal skills loader that implements Anthropic‚Äôs Agent Skills specification for any AI coding agent. It brings Claude Code‚Äôs skills system to Cursor, Windsurf, Aider, and other agents with 100% compatibility.

Why OpenSkills Matters

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy OpenSkills Matters‚Äù

The Problem

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Problem‚Äù

Each AI coding agent has its own way of handling specialized capabilities:

  • Claude Code has a built-in skills system with marketplace
  • Cursor uses custom rules and instructions
  • Windsurf has its own knowledge management
  • Aider relies on conventions and prompts

This fragmentation means skills and workflows don‚Äôt transfer between agents.

The Solution

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Solution‚Äù

OpenSkills provides a unified skills format that works across all agents:

  • Same prompt format - <available_skills> XML structure
  • Same marketplace - Access Anthropic‚Äôs official skills
  • Same folder structure - Uses .claude/skills/ by default
  • Same SKILL.md format - YAML frontmatter + markdown instructions
  • Progressive disclosure - Load skills on demand, not upfront

Key Features

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Features‚Äù

1. Universal Compatibility

Section titled ‚Äú1. Universal Compatibility‚Äù

OpenSkills works with any AI coding agent by using CLI commands instead of proprietary tool calls:

AspectClaude CodeOpenSkills
InvocationSkill("pdf")openskills read pdf
Prompt Format<available_skills> XMLIdentical
Folder Structure.claude/skills/Identical
SKILL.md FormatYAML + markdownIdentical

2. Multiple Installation Sources

Section titled ‚Äú2. Multiple Installation Sources‚Äù

Install skills from various sources:

3. Progressive Disclosure

Section titled ‚Äú3. Progressive Disclosure‚Äù

Skills load only when needed, keeping your agent‚Äôs context clean and focused. When the agent needs a skill:

  1. Agent scans <available_skills> in AGENTS.md
  2. Agent executes openskills read <skill-name>
  3. Full skill instructions load into context
  4. Agent follows instructions to complete task

4. Bundled Resources Support

Section titled ‚Äú4. Bundled Resources Support‚Äù

Skills can include supporting resources:

Quick Start Guide

Section titled ‚ÄúQuick Start Guide‚Äù

Step 1: Install OpenSkills

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 1: Install OpenSkills‚Äù

Requires Node.js 20.6+ and Git.

Step 2: Install Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 2: Install Skills‚Äù

Available skills from Anthropic‚Äôs marketplace:

  • pdf - PDF manipulation (extract, merge, split, forms)
  • xlsx - Spreadsheet creation and analysis
  • docx - Document creation with tracked changes
  • pptx - Presentation creation and editing
  • canvas-design - Create posters and visual designs
  • mcp-builder - Build Model Context Protocol servers
  • skill-creator - Guide for authoring skills

Step 3: Sync to AGENTS.md

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 3: Sync to AGENTS.md‚Äù

This updates your AGENTS.md file with the <available_skills> section:

Advanced Usage

Section titled ‚ÄúAdvanced Usage‚Äù

Global vs Project Installation

Section titled ‚ÄúGlobal vs Project Installation‚Äù

Universal Mode for Multi-Agent Setups

Section titled ‚ÄúUniversal Mode for Multi-Agent Setups‚Äù

If you use Claude Code alongside other agents:

This installs to .agent/skills/ to avoid conflicts with Claude Code‚Äôs native marketplace.

Priority order:

  1. ./.agent/skills/ (project universal)
  2. ~/.agent/skills/ (global universal)
  3. ./.claude/skills/ (project)
  4. ~/.claude/skills/ (global)

Local Development with Symlinks

Section titled ‚ÄúLocal Development with Symlinks‚Äù

For active skill development:

Creating Custom Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúCreating Custom Skills‚Äù

Minimal Structure

Section titled ‚ÄúMinimal Structure‚Äù

Full Structure with Resources

Section titled ‚ÄúFull Structure with Resources‚Äù

Publishing

Section titled ‚ÄúPublishing‚Äù
  1. Create a GitHub repository with your skill
  2. Users install with: openskills install username/repo-name

Use Cases

Section titled ‚ÄúUse Cases‚Äù

1. Standardize Skills Across Teams

Section titled ‚Äú1. Standardize Skills Across Teams‚Äù

Use OpenSkills to share skills across your organization regardless of which AI agent team members prefer:

2. Extend Claude Code‚Äôs Marketplace

Section titled ‚Äú2. Extend Claude Code‚Äôs Marketplace‚Äù

Install skills from any GitHub repository, not just Anthropic‚Äôs marketplace:

3. Private Enterprise Skills

Section titled ‚Äú3. Private Enterprise Skills‚Äù

Keep proprietary skills in private repositories:

4. Multi-Agent Workflows

Section titled ‚Äú4. Multi-Agent Workflows‚Äù

Use the same skills whether you‚Äôre in Claude Code, Cursor, or Windsurf:

Why CLI Instead of MCP?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy CLI Instead of MCP?‚Äù

OpenSkills uses CLI commands rather than MCP (Model Context Protocol) because:

  1. Skills are static instructions - Not dynamic tools requiring server connections
  2. No server needed - Skills are just markdown files
  3. Universal compatibility - CLI works with any agent
  4. Follows Anthropic‚Äôs design - Skills were designed as SKILL.md files
  5. Simpler for users - No server management required

MCP and skills solve different problems. OpenSkills implements the skills spec as designed.

Best Practices

Section titled ‚ÄúBest Practices‚Äù

1. Keep Skills Focused

Section titled ‚Äú1. Keep Skills Focused‚Äù

Each skill should handle one specific domain. Don‚Äôt create ‚Äúdo everything‚Äù skills.

2. Write Clear Descriptions

Section titled ‚Äú2. Write Clear Descriptions‚Äù

The description helps agents decide when to load the skill:

3. Use Progressive Disclosure

Section titled ‚Äú3. Use Progressive Disclosure‚Äù

Put detailed instructions in SKILL.md, not the description. This keeps the <available_skills> section compact.

4. Include Examples

Section titled ‚Äú4. Include Examples‚Äù

Help agents understand how to use your skill with concrete examples in the instructions.

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled ‚ÄúComparison with Alternatives‚Äù
FeatureOpenSkillsCustom PromptsMCP
UniversalYesPer-agentRequires support
Progressive LoadingYesNoYes
Marketplace AccessYesNoDifferent
Setup ComplexityLowVariesHigher
Bundled ResourcesYesLimitedYes

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

OpenSkills democratizes AI agent skills by making Anthropic‚Äôs well-designed skills system available to all agents. Whether you‚Äôre using Claude Code, Cursor, Windsurf, or Aider, you can now benefit from:

  • Standardized skills format across agents
  • Access to Anthropic‚Äôs marketplace via GitHub
  • Progressive disclosure for clean contexts
  • Easy skill sharing within teams and communities

Get started today:

Personal AI Infrastructure (PAI): Build Your Own AI-Powered Operating System

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Personal AI Infrastructure (PAI): Build Your Own AI-Powered Operating System

Section titled ‚ÄúPersonal AI Infrastructure (PAI): Build Your Own AI-Powered Operating System‚Äù

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Right now, the most powerful AI setups are being built inside companies for efficiency and profits. But what if you could have the same sophisticated AI infrastructure available to everyone? That‚Äôs exactly what Personal AI Infrastructure (PAI) delivers.

Created by security researcher and AI pioneer Daniel Miessler, PAI is an open-source template for building your own AI-powered operating system. It‚Äôs the foundation for creating a Personal AI System that understands your larger goals and context, gets better over time, and works for you because it‚Äôs yours.

What is PAI?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is PAI?‚Äù

PAI (Personal AI Infrastructure) is open-source scaffolding built on Claude Code, designed to be platform-independent. The architecture, skills, and workflows are structured so future migrations to other AI platforms remain straightforward.

Core Philosophy

Section titled ‚ÄúCore Philosophy‚Äù

‚ÄúThe best AI in the world should be available to everyone.‚Äù

The purpose of technology is to serve humans‚Äînot the other way around. PAI enables regular people to use AI to help them flourish, not just tech workers inside corporations.

Core Components

Section titled ‚ÄúCore Components‚Äù

1. Skills System

Section titled ‚Äú1. Skills System‚Äù

Skills are self-contained AI capabilities with routing, workflows, and documentation. Each skill follows the ‚Äúskills-as-containers‚Äù pattern:

ComponentDescription
SkillsDomain expertise encoded as reusable modules (security analysis, content creation, research workflows)
AgentsSpecialized AI personalities for different tasks (engineer, researcher, designer)
HooksEvent-driven automation that captures work and manages state
HistoryAutomatic documentation system (UOCS) that captures everything

2. File-System-Based Context

Section titled ‚Äú2. File-System-Based Context‚Äù

Instead of cramming everything into massive prompts, PAI organizes knowledge into a hierarchical structure:

  • Projects: Active work with context
  • Methodologies: How you approach problems
  • Philosophy: Your principles and values
  • Tools: Technical capabilities
  • Tasks: Specific actions and workflows

Each directory contains specialized knowledge loaded only when needed.

3. Native Fabric Patterns

Section titled ‚Äú3. Native Fabric Patterns‚Äù

PAI includes native integration with Fabric patterns‚Äî248+ AI patterns for content analysis and generation:

  • extract_wisdom: Extract key insights from content
  • summarize: Create concise summaries
  • threat_modeling: Security analysis workflows
  • And 245+ more patterns

Patterns run directly in Claude‚Äôs context using your subscription‚Äôs model, with full conversation history access.

The Thirteen Founding Principles

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Thirteen Founding Principles‚Äù

PAI is built on 13 foundational principles:

  1. Clear Thinking + Prompting is King - Quality outcomes depend on quality thinking
  2. Scaffolding > Model - System architecture matters more than AI model power
  3. As Deterministic as Possible - Same input ‚Üí Same output
  4. Code Before Prompts - Write code to solve problems, prompts to orchestrate
  5. Spec / Test / Evals First - Define expected behavior before implementation
  6. UNIX Philosophy - Do one thing well, compose tools through standard interfaces
  7. ENG / SRE Principles - Apply software engineering rigor to AI systems
  8. CLI as Interface - Every operation accessible via command line
  9. Goal ‚Üí Code ‚Üí CLI ‚Üí Prompts ‚Üí Agents - Proper development pipeline
  10. Meta / Self Update System - Systems that improve themselves
  11. Custom Skill Management - Skills as organizational units
  12. Custom History System - Automatic capture of valuable work
  13. Custom Agent Personalities - Specialized agents for different tasks

SkillsMP: The Open Marketplace for AI Agent Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúSkillsMP: The Open Marketplace for AI Agent Skills‚Äù

AI coding assistants have become indispensable tools for developers, but their capabilities are often limited to what comes built-in. SkillsMP changes this by providing an open marketplace where developers can discover, install, and share skills across multiple AI platforms.

What is SkillsMP?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is SkillsMP?‚Äù

SkillsMP is an open-source marketplace hosting over 31,000 agent skills that work seamlessly with the most popular AI coding assistants:

  • Claude Code - Anthropic‚Äôs official CLI tool
  • Codex CLI - OpenAI‚Äôs command-line interface
  • ChatGPT - The world‚Äôs most popular AI assistant

All skills use the unified SKILL.md format, ensuring compatibility across platforms and making it easy to share capabilities between different AI tools.

The SKILL.md Standard

Section titled ‚ÄúThe SKILL.md Standard‚Äù

The SKILL.md format is the foundation of the agent skills ecosystem. It defines modular capabilities through:

  • Instructions - Clear guidance for the AI on what the skill does and how to use it
  • Scripts (optional) - Supporting code that extends functionality
  • Templates (optional) - Pre-built structures for common outputs

Key Characteristics

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Characteristics‚Äù

Skills are model-invoked, not user-invoked. This means the AI assistant decides when to activate a skill based on the context of your request, rather than requiring explicit commands.

Installation Paths

Section titled ‚ÄúInstallation Paths‚Äù

  10. Research - Information gathering
  11. Databases - Database operations
  12. Blockchain - Web3 and crypto tools

Agent Skills for Context Engineering: Build Production-Grade AI Agent Systems

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Agent Skills for Context Engineering: Build Production-Grade AI Agent Systems

Section titled ‚ÄúAgent Skills for Context Engineering: Build Production-Grade AI Agent Systems‚Äù

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI development, context engineering has emerged as one of the most critical disciplines for building effective agent systems. Unlike prompt engineering, which focuses on crafting effective instructions, context engineering addresses the holistic curation of all information entering a model‚Äôs limited attention window.

Agent Skills for Context Engineering by Murat Can Koylan is a comprehensive, open-source collection designed to teach the art and science of curating context to maximize agent effectiveness across any platform.

What is Context Engineering?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is Context Engineering?‚Äù

Context engineering is the discipline of managing the language model‚Äôs context window. The fundamental challenge is that context windows are constrained not by raw token capacity but by attention mechanics.

The Core Problem

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Core Problem‚Äù

As context length increases, models exhibit predictable degradation patterns:

  • Lost-in-the-Middle Phenomenon - Information in the middle of long contexts gets less attention
  • U-Shaped Attention Curves - Models focus more on beginning and end of context
  • Attention Scarcity - Limited ‚Äúattention budget‚Äù must be allocated wisely

The Solution

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Solution‚Äù

Effective context engineering means finding the smallest possible set of high-signal tokens that maximize the likelihood of desired outcomes. This requires understanding what context is, how it degrades, and how to optimize it.

Skills Overview

Section titled ‚ÄúSkills Overview‚Äù

The collection is organized into three tiers of increasing complexity.

Foundational Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúFoundational Skills‚Äù

These skills establish the foundational understanding required for all subsequent context engineering work.

SkillDescription
context-fundamentalsUnderstand what context is, why it matters, and the anatomy of context in agent systems
context-degradationRecognize patterns of context failure: lost-in-middle, poisoning, distraction, and clash
context-compressionDesign and evaluate compression strategies for long-running sessions

Architectural Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúArchitectural Skills‚Äù

These skills cover the patterns and structures for building effective agent systems.

SkillDescription
multi-agent-patternsMaster orchestrator, peer-to-peer, and hierarchical multi-agent architectures
memory-systemsDesign short-term, long-term, and graph-based memory architectures
tool-designBuild tools that agents can use effectively

Operational Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúOperational Skills‚Äù

These skills address the ongoing operation and optimization of agent systems.

SkillDescription
context-optimizationApply compaction, masking, and caching strategies
evaluationBuild evaluation frameworks for agent systems

Key Concepts Deep Dive

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Concepts Deep Dive‚Äù

1. Context Fundamentals

Section titled ‚Äú1. Context Fundamentals‚Äù

Understanding the anatomy of context in agent systems is essential:

Components of Context:

  • System prompts
  • Tool definitions
  • Retrieved documents
  • Message history
  • Tool outputs

Each component competes for limited attention. Effective agents prioritize high-signal information and compress or eliminate low-signal content.

2. Context Degradation Patterns

Section titled ‚Äú2. Context Degradation Patterns‚Äù

Recognizing failure patterns helps prevent them:

Lost-in-Middle: Critical information placed in the middle of long contexts receives less model attention.

Context Poisoning: Bad or conflicting information corrupts the model‚Äôs understanding.

Context Distraction: Irrelevant information diverts attention from important content.

Context Clash: Contradictory instructions or data create confusion.

3. Multi-Agent Patterns

Section titled ‚Äú3. Multi-Agent Patterns‚Äù

Three primary architectures for multi-agent systems:

Orchestrator Pattern: A central agent coordinates specialized sub-agents, managing task delegation and result aggregation.

Peer-to-Peer Pattern: Agents communicate directly without central coordination, suitable for collaborative tasks.

Hierarchical Pattern: Layered agent structures where higher-level agents manage groups of lower-level agents.

4. Memory Systems

Section titled ‚Äú4. Memory Systems‚Äù

Effective agents require multiple memory types:

Short-term Memory:

  • Recent conversation context
  • Current task state
  • Immediate working memory

Long-term Memory:

  • Persistent knowledge stores
  • User preferences
  • Historical patterns

Graph-based Memory:

  • Relationship maps between concepts
  • Entity connections
  • Semantic networks

Installation and Usage

Section titled ‚ÄúInstallation and Usage‚Äù

For Claude Code

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Claude Code‚Äù

Install skills by referencing the repository or copying skill folders into your configured skills directory:

When working on context engineering tasks, activate relevant skills to load their instructions.

For Cursor

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Cursor‚Äù

Copy skill content into .cursorrules or create project-specific rules files:

The skills provide the context and guidelines that Cursor‚Äôs agent needs for effective context engineering.

For Custom Implementations

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Custom Implementations‚Äù

Extract the principles and patterns from any skill and implement them in your agent framework. The skills are deliberately platform-agnostic, making them applicable to any LLM-based system.

Recommended Use Scenarios

Section titled ‚ÄúRecommended Use Scenarios‚Äù

1. Building Production Agent Systems

Section titled ‚Äú1. Building Production Agent Systems‚Äù

When developing agents for real-world deployment:

  • Start with fundamentals - Understand context anatomy before optimization
  • Design memory early - Memory architecture affects all downstream decisions
  • Plan for degradation - Build in monitoring and recovery mechanisms
  • Test at scale - Evaluation frameworks catch issues before production

2. Optimizing Existing Agents

Section titled ‚Äú2. Optimizing Existing Agents‚Äù

For teams with existing agent systems:

  • Diagnose context issues - Use degradation patterns to identify problems
  • Apply compression strategies - Reduce token usage without losing signal
  • Implement caching - Avoid redundant context loading
  • Add instrumentation - Build visibility into context usage

3. Multi-Agent Architecture Design

Section titled ‚Äú3. Multi-Agent Architecture Design‚Äù

When building systems with multiple coordinating agents:

  • Choose the right pattern - Orchestrator vs peer-to-peer vs hierarchical
  • Design communication protocols - How agents share context
  • Manage shared memory - Coordination without conflicts
  • Handle failures gracefully - Recovery when agents fail

4. Educational and Training Purposes

Section titled ‚Äú4. Educational and Training Purposes‚Äù

For learning about agent development:

  • Progressive disclosure - Skills build on each other logically
  • Practical examples - Python pseudocode demonstrates concepts
  • Platform-agnostic - Learn principles, not vendor lock-in
  • Open source - Study, modify, and contribute

Daily Workflow Examples

Best Practices

Section titled ‚ÄúBest Practices‚Äù

Design Philosophy

Section titled ‚ÄúDesign Philosophy‚Äù

The collection follows three key principles:

1. Progressive Disclosure

Each skill is structured for efficient context use. At startup, agents load only skill names and descriptions. Full content loads only when a skill is activated for relevant tasks.

2. Platform Agnosticism

These skills focus on transferable principles rather than vendor-specific implementations. The patterns work across Claude Code, Cursor, and any agent platform that supports skills or allows custom instructions.

3. Conceptual Foundation with Practical Examples

Scripts and examples demonstrate concepts using Python pseudocode that works across environments without requiring specific dependency installations.

Why Agent Skills?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Agent Skills?‚Äù

vs. Custom Rules:

  • Standardized structure enables sharing and reuse
  • Progressive disclosure reduces initial context cost
  • Community contributions expand coverage

vs. Framework Documentation:

  • Focuses on principles, not implementation details
  • Transferable across platforms
  • Practical orientation for production systems

Troubleshooting and FAQ

Section titled ‚ÄúTroubleshooting and FAQ‚Äù

Common Questions

Section titled ‚ÄúCommon Questions‚Äù

Q: Do these skills work with any LLM? A: Yes, the principles are LLM-agnostic. Examples use Python pseudocode that can be adapted to any environment.

Q: How do I know which skill to use? A: Start with fundamentals, then move to architectural skills for design decisions, and operational skills for optimization.

Q: Can I contribute new skills? A: Absolutely! Follow the template structure and submit pull requests. Community contributions are welcome.

Q: Are there costs associated with using these skills? A: No, the repository is MIT licensed. However, the LLMs you use with these skills may have associated costs.

Q: How do skills handle context limits? A: Progressive disclosure means only relevant content loads. Each skill is designed to stay under 500 lines.

Troubleshooting

Section titled ‚ÄúTroubleshooting‚Äù

Skills not loading:

  • Ensure skill folder structure is correct
  • Check that SKILL.md exists in skill directory
  • Verify file permissions

Poor agent performance:

  • Review context-degradation skill for diagnostic patterns
  • Check if context window is being exceeded
  • Evaluate information signal-to-noise ratio

Multi-agent coordination issues:

  • Review multi-agent-patterns skill
  • Check message passing protocols
  • Verify shared memory access patterns

Section titled ‚ÄúReference Links‚Äù

  • Skill Template: Template folder in repository
  • Examples: X-to-Book System example
  • Agent Skills Specification: Follow repository for updates

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Context engineering is becoming as fundamental to AI development as software engineering principles are to traditional development. Agent Skills for Context Engineering provides a structured, open, and platform-agnostic foundation for mastering this critical discipline.

Whether you‚Äôre building your first agent or optimizing production multi-agent systems, these skills offer the conceptual foundation and practical guidance needed for success. The progressive disclosure design means you can start small and expand as needed, while the platform-agnostic approach ensures your learning transfers across tools and frameworks.

The AI agent ecosystem is maturing rapidly, and context engineering will be a key differentiator between agents that work and agents that work well. Start with the fundamentals, understand degradation patterns, and build systems that manage context effectively.

Explore the full collection at Agent Skills for Context Engineering and join the community building better agent systems.

Precautions & Troubleshooting

Section titled ‚ÄúPrecautions & Troubleshooting‚Äù

Common Issues and Solutions

Section titled ‚ÄúCommon Issues and Solutions‚Äù

Issue: Code doesn‚Äôt match design exactly

Solution: Ensure your Figma file uses Auto Layout and constraints properly. Avoid absolute positioning where possible.

Issue: Too many nested divs

Solution: Flatten complex layer structures in Figma before exporting. Use Groups sparingly and prefer Frames with Auto Layout.

Issue: Missing Tailwind classes

Solution: Make sure your Tailwind configuration includes all necessary color and spacing values used in your design.

Limitations to Know

Section titled ‚ÄúLimitations to Know‚Äù
  • Complex animations require manual implementation
  • Custom fonts need to be installed in your project separately
  • SVG icons may require optimization after export
  • Interactive states (hover, focus) need manual addition

MCPCAN: Centralized MCP Service Management Platform

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

MCPCAN: Centralized MCP Service Management Platform

Section titled ‚ÄúMCPCAN: Centralized MCP Service Management Platform‚Äù

As the Model Context Protocol (MCP) ecosystem continues to expand, managing multiple MCP services across development and production environments has become increasingly complex. MCPCAN emerges as a comprehensive solution - a centralized management platform that deploys MCP services using containerized approaches while providing robust security, monitoring, and protocol conversion capabilities.

What is MCPCAN?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is MCPCAN?‚Äù

MCPCAN is an open-source, Kubernetes-native platform designed for DevOps teams to manage the full lifecycle of MCP services. It addresses critical challenges in MCP deployment:

  • Configuration Conflicts: Container isolation eliminates system-level conflicts
  • Security Vulnerabilities: Built-in token verification and permission management
  • Deployment Complexity: One-click deployment with Helm charts
  • Protocol Fragmentation: Seamless conversion between SSE, STDIO, and STREAMABLEHTTP

Core Features

Section titled ‚ÄúCore Features‚Äù

1. Unified Management Dashboard

Section titled ‚Äú1. Unified Management Dashboard‚Äù

The Vue.js-powered web interface provides centralized control over all MCP service instances:

  • Visual service configuration management
  • Real-time status monitoring
  • Batch operations support
  • Service lifecycle control (start/stop/restart)

2. Multi-Protocol Support

Section titled ‚Äú2. Multi-Protocol Support‚Äù

MCPCAN supports three primary MCP access protocols:

ProtocolUse CaseCharacteristics
SSEReal-time streamingServer-Sent Events for continuous updates
STDIOLocal integrationStandard input/output for CLI tools
STREAMABLEHTTPWeb applicationsHTTP-based streaming with broad compatibility

The platform handles protocol conversion automatically, allowing services written for one protocol to be accessed via another.

3. Security Authentication System

Section titled ‚Äú3. Security Authentication System‚Äù

Security is built into MCPCAN‚Äôs core architecture:

  • Token Verification: Every MCP service request is validated
  • Identity Authentication: User-level access control
  • Permission Management: Role-based service access
  • Audit Logging: Complete request tracking

4. Container-Based Deployment

Section titled ‚Äú4. Container-Based Deployment‚Äù

Each MCP service runs in its own isolated container:

Benefits include:

  • Resource isolation and limits
  • Independent scaling
  • Easy rollback and versioning
  • Consistent environments

5. Real-Time Monitoring

Section titled ‚Äú5. Real-Time Monitoring‚Äù

Comprehensive observability features:

  • Service health dashboards
  • Performance metrics collection
  • Resource utilization tracking
  • Alert configuration

Architecture Overview

Section titled ‚ÄúArchitecture Overview‚Äù

MCPCAN follows a microservices architecture built on Kubernetes:

Technology Stack

Section titled ‚ÄúTechnology Stack‚Äù

Frontend:

  • Vue.js 3.5+ with Composition API
  • TypeScript for type safety
  • Pinia for state management
  • Element Plus UI components
  • Vite build tooling

Backend:

  • Go 1.24.2+ for high performance
  • Gin web framework
  • gRPC for internal communication
  • MySQL for persistent storage
  • Redis for caching and sessions

Installation Guide

Section titled ‚ÄúInstallation Guide‚Äù

Quick Installation (Recommended)

Section titled ‚ÄúQuick Installation (Recommended)‚Äù

For rapid deployment with automated setup:

This automatically installs:

  • k3s (lightweight Kubernetes)
  • ingress-nginx
  • Helm 3
  • MCPCAN components

Custom Installation

Section titled ‚ÄúCustom Installation‚Äù

For existing Kubernetes clusters or custom configurations:

Section titled ‚ÄúConfiguration Options‚Äù

ParameterDescriptionDefault
domainPlatform access domainlocalhost
tls.enabledEnable HTTPSfalse
mysql.storageSizeDatabase storage10Gi
redis.enabledEnable Redis cachingtrue

Usage Scenarios

Section titled ‚ÄúUsage Scenarios‚Äù

Scenario 1: Enterprise MCP Gateway

Section titled ‚ÄúScenario 1: Enterprise MCP Gateway‚Äù

Deploy MCPCAN as a centralized gateway for all AI assistant tools:

  1. Register MCP services through the marketplace
  2. Configure access tokens for each team
  3. Monitor usage and performance
  4. Scale services based on demand

Scenario 2: Development Team Sandbox

Section titled ‚ÄúScenario 2: Development Team Sandbox‚Äù

Provide isolated MCP environments for developers:

  • Each developer gets dedicated service instances
  • Shared service pool for common tools
  • Development/staging/production separation

Scenario 3: Multi-Tenant Platform

Section titled ‚ÄúScenario 3: Multi-Tenant Platform‚Äù

Operate MCP services for multiple clients:

  • Tenant isolation through namespaces
  • Per-tenant resource quotas
  • Separate billing and monitoring

Best Practices

Section titled ‚ÄúBest Practices‚Äù

Security Hardening

Section titled ‚ÄúSecurity Hardening‚Äù
  1. Enable TLS: Always use HTTPS in production
  2. Rotate Tokens: Implement regular token rotation
  3. Network Policies: Restrict inter-service communication
  4. Audit Everything: Enable comprehensive logging

Performance Optimization

Section titled ‚ÄúPerformance Optimization‚Äù
  1. Resource Limits: Set appropriate CPU/memory limits
  2. Horizontal Scaling: Use HPA for auto-scaling
  3. Caching: Leverage Redis for frequent requests
  4. Connection Pooling: Optimize database connections

Operational Excellence

Section titled ‚ÄúOperational Excellence‚Äù
  1. GitOps: Store configurations in Git
  2. Monitoring: Set up alerts for critical metrics
  3. Backup: Regular database backups
  4. Documentation: Maintain runbooks

The platform‚Äôs combination of container isolation, protocol flexibility, and built-in security makes it an excellent choice for teams looking to standardize their MCP operations while maintaining control over their infrastructure.

iOS App Store Submission: Complete Guide from Development to Review

iOS App Store Submission: Complete Guide from Development to Review

Section titled ‚ÄúiOS App Store Submission: Complete Guide from Development to Review‚Äù

Submitting an iOS app to the App Store can feel overwhelming for first-time developers. This guide walks you through the entire process, using our MoneyMind app as a real-world example. Whether you‚Äôre building with Flutter, SwiftUI, or UIKit, these steps apply to all iOS app submissions.

Overview

Section titled ‚ÄúOverview‚Äù

The App Store submission process involves several key stages:

  1. App Preparation - Icon, assets, and build configuration
  2. Certificates & Provisioning - Apple Distribution certificate setup
  3. App Store Connect Setup - App information, pricing, and screenshots
  4. Build Upload - Archive and upload via Xcode
  5. Review Submission - Final checklist and submission

Let‚Äôs dive into each step.

Step 1: App Icon Creation

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 1: App Icon Creation‚Äù

Your app icon is the first impression users get. Apple has strict requirements:

Icon Specifications

Section titled ‚ÄúIcon Specifications‚Äù
  • Size: 1024 √ó 1024 pixels
  • Format: PNG without transparency
  • Shape: Square (iOS automatically applies corner radius)
  • Safe Zone: Keep critical elements within 600-700px centered area

Generating Icons with AI

Section titled ‚ÄúGenerating Icons with AI‚Äù

Modern AI tools like ChatGPT and Gemini can help design app icons:

  1. Describe your app‚Äôs purpose and brand identity
  2. Request multiple variations
  3. Iterate on the best concepts
  4. Export at 1024√ó1024px without transparency

Flutter Icon Configuration

Section titled ‚ÄúFlutter Icon Configuration‚Äù

For Flutter projects, use flutter_launcher_icons:

Run the icon generator:

Step 2: Apple Distribution Certificate

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 2: Apple Distribution Certificate‚Äù

You need an Apple Distribution certificate to submit apps to the App Store.

Certificate Types

Section titled ‚ÄúCertificate Types‚Äù
Certificate TypePurposeRecommended
Apple DistributionApp Store, TestFlight, Ad Hoc‚úÖ Yes
iOS DistributionLegacy - being deprecated‚ùå No
Mac App DistributionMac App Store onlyMac only

Creating a Distribution Certificate

Section titled ‚ÄúCreating a Distribution Certificate‚Äù
  1. Open Keychain Access on your Mac
  2. Select Keychain Access > Certificate Assistant > Request a Certificate from a Certificate Authority
  3. Enter your email and select ‚ÄúSaved to disk‚Äù
  4. Go to Apple Developer Portal
  5. Navigate to Certificates, Identifiers & Profiles
  6. Click + to create new certificate
  7. Select Apple Distribution
  8. Upload your Certificate Signing Request (CSR)
  9. Download and double-click to install

Pro Tip: Xcode Automatic Signing

Section titled ‚ÄúPro Tip: Xcode Automatic Signing‚Äù

For simpler projects, enable automatic signing in Xcode:

  1. Open your project in Xcode
  2. Select your target
  3. Go to Signing & Capabilities
  4. Check Automatically manage signing
  5. Select your team

Step 3: Build and Upload to App Store Connect

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 3: Build and Upload to App Store Connect‚Äù

Archive Your App

Section titled ‚ÄúArchive Your App‚Äù
  1. In Xcode, select Product > Archive
  2. Wait for the build to complete
  3. The Organizer window opens automatically

Upload to App Store Connect

Section titled ‚ÄúUpload to App Store Connect‚Äù
  1. In the Organizer, select your archive
  2. Click Distribute App
  3. Select App Store Connect
  4. Choose Upload
  5. Follow the prompts

Build Processing

Section titled ‚ÄúBuild Processing‚Äù

After uploading:

  • Apple processes your build (5-30 minutes)
  • You‚Äôll receive an email when processing completes
  • Check for any issues in App Store Connect

Important: Check your email regularly! Apple may flag issues that prevent your build from appearing in App Store Connect.

Step 4: App Store Connect Configuration

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 4: App Store Connect Configuration‚Äù

App Information

Section titled ‚ÄúApp Information‚Äù

Fill in essential details:

  • Name: MoneyMind ÁúÅÈí±ÊÄùÁª¥
  • Subtitle: Â∏ÆÂä©‰Ω† Âà∂ÂÆöÁúÅÈí±ÁõÆÊ†á„ÄÅËÆ∞ÂΩïÊØèÊó•ÁúÅÈí±Ë°åÂä®
  • Category: Finance (Primary), Lifestyle (Secondary)

Privacy Policy & Terms of Service

Section titled ‚ÄúPrivacy Policy & Terms of Service‚Äù

Apple requires privacy policy and terms of service URLs:

  1. Create privacy policy and terms documents
  2. Host them on a publicly accessible URL
  3. Enter URLs in App Store Connect

We host our documents on our website:

  • Privacy Policy: https://yoursite.com/privacy
  • Terms of Service: https://yoursite.com/terms

Pricing and Availability

Section titled ‚ÄúPricing and Availability‚Äù

Configure your app‚Äôs pricing:

  • Select price tier or choose ‚ÄúFree‚Äù
  • Choose availability by country/region
  • Set pre-order options if desired

Age Rating

Section titled ‚ÄúAge Rating‚Äù

Complete the age rating questionnaire:

  • Answer honestly about app content
  • Categories include violence, gambling, mature themes
  • Your rating is automatically calculated

Content Rights

Section titled ‚ÄúContent Rights‚Äù

Declare if your app contains, shows, or accesses third-party content.

This prevents Apple from asking about encryption compliance on each submission.

Step 6: Screenshots

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 6: Screenshots‚Äù

Screenshots are crucial for App Store presence. You need them for multiple device sizes.

iPhone Screenshots

Section titled ‚ÄúiPhone Screenshots‚Äù
  • Required Size: 1242 √ó 2678 pixels (6.7‚Äù display)
  • Preparation: Remove top status bar (approximately 100px)
  • Count: 1-10 screenshots

iPad Screenshots

Section titled ‚ÄúiPad Screenshots‚Äù
  • Required Size: 2064 √ó 2752 pixels (12.9‚Äù display)
  • Preparation: Remove top status bar (approximately 36px)
  • Count: 1-10 screenshots

Screenshot Tips

Section titled ‚ÄúScreenshot Tips‚Äù
  1. Show key features - Highlight your app‚Äôs best functionality
  2. Add captions - Brief text explaining each screen
  3. Use device frames - Optional but professional-looking
  4. Maintain consistency - Same style across all screenshots
  5. Localize - Different screenshots for different languages

Step 7: Localization (i18n)

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 7: Localization (i18n)‚Äù

App Store Connect supports multiple languages:

  1. Go to App Information
  2. Click + next to your primary language
  3. Add supported languages
  4. Fill in localized:
    • App name
    • Subtitle
    • Description
    • Keywords
    • Screenshots

Key Languages to Consider

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Languages to Consider‚Äù
  • English (US/UK)
  • Simplified Chinese
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • German
  • French
  • Spanish

Step 8: Submit for Review

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 8: Submit for Review‚Äù

Pre-Submission Checklist

Section titled ‚ÄúPre-Submission Checklist‚Äù
  • App icon uploaded
  • Screenshots for all device sizes
  • Privacy policy URL working
  • Terms of service URL working
  • App description complete
  • Keywords optimized
  • Age rating completed
  • Build uploaded and processed
  • Build selected in App Store Connect
  • Contact information accurate

Submit

Section titled ‚ÄúSubmit‚Äù
  1. Navigate to your app in App Store Connect
  2. Select your app version
  3. Click Submit for Review
  4. Answer review questions
  5. Confirm submission

Review Timeline

Section titled ‚ÄúReview Timeline‚Äù
  • Initial Review: Usually 24-48 hours
  • Rejection Response: Typically within 24 hours of resubmission
  • Expedited Reviews: Available for critical issues

Common Rejection Reasons & Solutions

Section titled ‚ÄúCommon Rejection Reasons & Solutions‚Äù

1. Guideline 2.1 - App Completeness

Section titled ‚Äú1. Guideline 2.1 - App Completeness‚Äù

Issue: App crashes, has placeholder content, or incomplete features.

Solution: Thoroughly test before submission. Remove any TODO or placeholder text.

2. Guideline 2.3 - Accurate Metadata

Section titled ‚Äú2. Guideline 2.3 - Accurate Metadata‚Äù

Issue: Screenshots don‚Äôt match actual app, misleading descriptions.

Solution: Update screenshots after every major UI change.

3. Guideline 5.1.1 - Data Collection and Storage

Section titled ‚Äú3. Guideline 5.1.1 - Data Collection and Storage‚Äù

Issue: Missing privacy policy or improper data handling disclosure.

Solution: Create comprehensive privacy policy, declare all data collection in App Store Connect.

4. Guideline 4.2 - Minimum Functionality

Section titled ‚Äú4. Guideline 4.2 - Minimum Functionality‚Äù

Issue: App is too simple or doesn‚Äôt provide enough value.

Solution: Ensure your app provides meaningful functionality beyond what a website could offer.

Tips for Success

Section titled ‚ÄúTips for Success‚Äù

1. Test on Real Devices

Section titled ‚Äú1. Test on Real Devices‚Äù

Simulator testing isn‚Äôt enough. Test on:

  • Multiple iPhone models
  • iPads (if universal app)
  • Oldest supported iOS version

2. Monitor Email

Section titled ‚Äú2. Monitor Email‚Äù

Apple communicates via email for:

  • Build processing issues
  • Review status updates
  • Rejection reasons
  • App approval notifications

3. Respond Quickly to Rejections

Section titled ‚Äú3. Respond Quickly to Rejections‚Äù

Fast, professional responses to rejections:

  • Show Apple you‚Äôre engaged
  • Address all points raised
  • Ask for clarification if needed

4. Keep TestFlight Active

Section titled ‚Äú4. Keep TestFlight Active‚Äù

Use TestFlight for:

  • Beta testing before submission
  • Quick iteration on fixes
  • User feedback collection

5. Plan for Review Time

Section titled ‚Äú5. Plan for Review Time‚Äù

Don‚Äôt submit at the last minute:

  • Allow 1-2 weeks buffer for reviews
  • Account for potential rejections
  • Holiday periods may have longer queues

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Submitting to the App Store requires attention to detail and patience. By following this guide and preparing thoroughly, you can navigate the process smoothly and get your app into users‚Äô hands.

Key takeaways:

  1. Prepare assets early - Icon, screenshots, and metadata take time
  2. Test thoroughly - Real device testing prevents rejections
  3. Read guidelines - Apple‚Äôs guidelines evolve; stay updated
  4. Be responsive - Quick responses to Apple expedite reviews
  5. Monitor communications - Email is your lifeline to Apple

Good luck with your App Store submission!

Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code

Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code

Section titled ‚ÄúGoogle Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code‚Äù

In November 2025, Google introduced Code Wiki, a revolutionary platform that addresses one of software development‚Äôs most persistent challenges: keeping documentation synchronized with code. Powered by Gemini AI, Code Wiki automatically generates and maintains comprehensive, always-up-to-date documentation for any code repository.

What is Google Code Wiki?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is Google Code Wiki?‚Äù

Code Wiki is a new platform designed for the agentic era of software development. It maintains a continuously updated, structured wiki for code repositories, automatically regenerating documentation after every code change.

‚ÄúA new perspective on development for the agentic era. Gemini-generated documentation, always up-to-date.‚Äù

The Documentation Problem

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Documentation Problem‚Äù

Reading and understanding existing code is one of the biggest, most expensive bottlenecks in software development. Traditional documentation:

  • Gets outdated quickly - Code changes faster than docs can be updated
  • Lacks context - Static docs don‚Äôt explain relationships between components
  • Requires manual effort - Engineers spend time writing docs instead of coding
  • Becomes inconsistent - Different authors, different styles, incomplete coverage

Code Wiki solves these problems through automated, AI-powered documentation generation.

Core Features & Highlights

Section titled ‚ÄúCore Features & Highlights‚Äù

1. Automatic Documentation Generation

Section titled ‚Äú1. Automatic Documentation Generation‚Äù

Code Wiki scans entire repositories and generates structured documentation automatically:

  • Full codebase analysis - Understands all files, functions, and relationships
  • Regeneration on every commit - Docs update automatically with each change
  • Architecture diagrams - Visual representations generated and kept current
  • Class and sequence diagrams - Technical visualizations for complex systems

2. Gemini-Powered Chat Interface

Section titled ‚Äú2. Gemini-Powered Chat Interface‚Äù

Each Code Wiki page includes an intelligent chat agent:

  • Context-aware Q&A - Ask specific questions about YOUR codebase
  • Full wiki knowledge - Chat uses the complete, current documentation as context
  • Direct code links - Answers include hyperlinks to relevant source files
  • Natural language queries - Ask questions in plain English

Example interactions:

  • ‚ÄúHow does the authentication module work?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhat functions call the database connection pool?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúExplain the data flow in the payment processing system‚Äù

3. Hyperlinked Navigation

Section titled ‚Äú3. Hyperlinked Navigation‚Äù

Every documentation element connects directly to source code:

  • Symbol linking - Click any function, class, or variable to see its definition
  • Cross-references - Navigate between related concepts seamlessly
  • File locations - Know exactly where code lives
  • Definition chains - Trace from high-level concepts to implementation details

4. Powered by NotebookLM

Section titled ‚Äú4. Powered by NotebookLM‚Äù

Code Wiki integrates with Google‚Äôs NotebookLM for enhanced documentation:

  • Video explanations - Auto-generated video walkthroughs of codebases
  • Interactive presentations - Architecture overviews with multimedia
  • Audio summaries - Listen to code explanations (coming soon)

Section titled ‚ÄúPrerequisites & Getting Started‚Äù

  2. Search for any public open-source repository

  • No maintenance overhead
  • Always current
  • Consistent formatting
  • Complete coverage

vs. Code Comments:

  • Higher-level understanding
  • Cross-file relationships
  • Visual diagrams
  • Searchable and navigable

vs. README files:

  • Comprehensive depth
  • Interactive chat
  • Auto-updated
  • Architecture views

Frequently Asked Questions

Section titled ‚ÄúFrequently Asked Questions‚Äù

Q: Is Code Wiki free? A: Public preview for open-source repos is free. Private repo pricing TBD.

Q: How quickly does documentation update? A: Documentation regenerates after each commit, typically within minutes.

Q: Can I customize the generated documentation? A: Currently documentation is fully automated. Custom templates may come later.

Q: Does Code Wiki support all programming languages? A: Gemini AI supports most popular languages. Quality may vary for niche languages.

Q: Is my code sent to Google‚Äôs servers? A: For public repos, yes. The CLI extension for private repos will enable local processing.

Q: Can I export the documentation? A: Export features are on the roadmap. Currently, documentation lives on codewiki.google.

Auto-Claude: Autonomous Multi-Session AI Coding That 10x Your Development Output

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Auto-Claude is a revolutionary desktop application created by AndyMik90 that transforms how developers interact with AI coding assistants. Unlike traditional single-session AI coding tools, Auto-Claude enables you to run up to 12 parallel Claude Code terminals simultaneously, each working on different tasks while maintaining complete isolation through git worktrees.

Whether you‚Äôre a ‚Äúvibe coder‚Äù just getting started or an experienced developer managing complex projects, Auto-Claude meets you where you are with autonomous agents that plan, code, and validate for you.

Key Highlights

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Highlights‚Äù
  • 10x Development Output: Run multiple builds simultaneously while maintaining code quality
  • 12 Parallel Agent Terminals: Clean layout with smart naming and one-click context injection
  • Git Worktree Isolation: All work happens safely without disturbing your main branch
  • Self-Validating QA: Built-in agents check their own work before you review
  • Cross-Session Memory: Agents remember insights across sessions using FalkorDB graph database
  • AI Merge Resolution: Intelligent conflict resolution when merging back to main
  • Cross-Platform: Desktop app runs on Mac, Windows, and Linux

3. Three-Phase Agent Pipeline

Section titled ‚Äú3. Three-Phase Agent Pipeline‚Äù

Phase 1: Spec Creation (3-8 phases)

  • Discovery ‚Äî Analyzes project structure and tech stack
  • Requirements ‚Äî Gathers requirements through interactive conversation
  • Research ‚Äî Validates external integrations against real documentation
  • Context Discovery ‚Äî Finds relevant files in your codebase
  • Spec Writer ‚Äî Creates comprehensive specification document
  • Spec Critic ‚Äî Self-critiques using extended thinking
  • Planner ‚Äî Breaks work into subtasks with dependencies
  • Validation ‚Äî Ensures all outputs are valid

Phase 2: Implementation

  • Planner Agent creates subtask-based implementation plan
  • Coder Agent implements subtasks one-by-one with verification
  • QA Reviewer validates all acceptance criteria
  • QA Fixer fixes issues in a self-healing loop (up to 50 iterations)

Phase 3: Merge

  • Conflict Detection identifies modified files
  • 3-Tier Resolution: Git auto-merge ‚Üí Conflict-only AI ‚Üí Full-file AI
  • Parallel Merge for multiple files simultaneously
  • Staged for Review before finalizing

FAQ

Section titled ‚ÄúFAQ‚Äù

Q: How is Auto-Claude different from regular Claude Code? A: Auto-Claude wraps Claude Code with parallel execution, git worktree isolation, self-validating QA, and cross-session memory. It‚Äôs a productivity multiplier, not a replacement.

Q: Can I use this with my existing project? A: Yes! Just ensure your project is a git repository. Auto-Claude creates isolated worktrees without modifying your main branch.

Q: How many agents should I run? A: Start with 2-4 and scale up based on your hardware. Each agent consumes Claude Code API credits separately.

Q: Does it work offline? A: The Memory Layer supports Ollama for fully offline operation, but Claude Code requires internet connectivity.

Q: What happens if an agent gets stuck? A: The QA Fixer runs up to 50 iterations in a self-healing loop. If it still fails, you can review and intervene manually.

Section titled ‚Äú3. Checkpoints System‚Äù

  • Instant Rewind: Tap Esc twice or use /rewind command to return to previous versions
  • Selective Restoration: Choose to restore code, conversation, or both
  • Multi-level Undo: Not just one level‚Äîcheckpoints are kept for each change

5. Hooks for Automated Workflows

  • PreToolUse: Lint before commits
  • SessionStart/End: Initialize or cleanup resources

Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI

Section titled ‚ÄúFabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI‚Äù

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI tools, Fabric stands out as a revolutionary open-source framework designed to bridge the gap between AI capabilities and human integration. Created by security researcher and AI enthusiast Daniel Miessler, Fabric addresses a fundamental problem: AI doesn‚Äôt have a capabilities problem‚Äîit has an integration problem.

What is Fabric?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is Fabric?‚Äù

Fabric is an open-source framework that organizes and manages AI prompts‚Äîcalled Patterns‚Äîin a modular, reusable system. Unlike scattered prompts across various tools and platforms, Fabric provides a centralized, command-line-first approach to collecting, organizing, and executing AI solutions.

The Philosophy Behind Fabric

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Philosophy Behind Fabric‚Äù

‚ÄúAI isn‚Äôt a thing; it‚Äôs a magnifier of a thing. And that thing is human creativity.‚Äù

Fabric‚Äôs philosophy centers on breaking complex problems into manageable components and applying AI to each piece systematically. This approach transforms AI from a mysterious black box into a practical, everyday tool.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Features and Highlights‚Äù

1. Pattern-Based Architecture

Section titled ‚Äú1. Pattern-Based Architecture‚Äù

Patterns are the core building blocks of Fabric. Each Pattern is a carefully crafted prompt designed for a specific real-world task:

  • extract_wisdom: Extract key insights from YouTube videos and podcasts
  • summarize: Create concise summaries of any content
  • analyze_claims: Evaluate claims for accuracy and validity
  • write_essay: Generate essays in your own voice
  • create_coding_feature: Generate code features with context
  • improve_writing: Enhance writing quality and clarity

With over 150+ built-in Patterns, Fabric covers diverse use cases from content creation to code analysis.

2. Multi-Model Support

Section titled ‚Äú2. Multi-Model Support‚Äù

Fabric supports an impressive array of AI providers:

  • OpenAI (GPT-4, GPT-4o, o1, o3)
  • Anthropic (Claude 4, Claude 4.5 Opus)
  • Google (Gemini)
  • Local models via Ollama
  • Azure OpenAI
  • Amazon Bedrock
  • Perplexity AI
  • Venice AI (privacy-focused)
  • Together AI
  • And many more‚Ä¶

3. Seamless CLI Integration

Section titled ‚Äú3. Seamless CLI Integration‚Äù

Fabric is built for the command line, making it perfect for developers and power users:

4. Context and Session Management

Section titled ‚Äú4. Context and Session Management‚Äù

Fabric supports persistent contexts and sessions:

  • Contexts: Pre-created background information added to all queries
  • Sessions: Maintain conversation history across multiple interactions
  • Variables: Dynamic pattern customization with {{variable}} syntax

5. REST API Server

Section titled ‚Äú5. REST API Server‚Äù

Fabric includes a built-in REST API server for integration with other applications:

Features include:

  • Chat completions with streaming
  • Pattern management (CRUD operations)
  • YouTube transcript extraction
  • Swagger/OpenAPI documentation

6. Web Interface

Section titled ‚Äú6. Web Interface‚Äù

A GUI alternative to the CLI is available for those who prefer visual interfaces, providing access to all Fabric functionality through a web browser.

Prerequisites

Section titled ‚ÄúPrerequisites‚Äù

Before installing Fabric, ensure you have:

  • Go 1.22+ (for source installation)
  • API keys for your preferred AI providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.)
  • yt-dlp (optional, for YouTube transcript extraction)
  • LaTeX distribution (optional, for PDF generation with to_pdf)

FAQ

Section titled ‚ÄúFAQ‚Äù

Q: Is Fabric free to use? A: Yes, Fabric is MIT licensed. However, you need API keys for AI providers, which may have costs.

Q: Can I use Fabric without internet? A: Yes, with local models through Ollama.

Q: How do I contribute patterns? A: Submit a pull request to the Fabric repository with your pattern in the data/patterns directory.

Q: Does Fabric store my data? A: Fabric processes data locally. Data is sent to AI providers based on your configuration.

Q: Can I use multiple models in one workflow? A: Yes, you can chain patterns with different models using shell pipes.

Whether you‚Äôre a developer, content creator, security researcher, or knowledge worker, Fabric‚Äôs pattern-based approach offers a powerful way to augment your capabilities with AI.

The project‚Äôs active development, growing community, and extensive pattern library make it an essential tool for anyone serious about leveraging AI effectively. Start with the basic patterns, explore the community contributions, and eventually create your own‚Äîthat‚Äôs the path to truly augmented human productivity.

PromptHub: Open-Source Local-First AI Prompt Management Tool

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Are you tired of searching through notebooks, documents, and chat histories to find your AI prompts? PromptHub solves this problem elegantly - it lets you manage prompts like code with version control, variable templates, and multi-model testing, while keeping all your data stored locally for maximum privacy.

PromptHub is an open-source, free AI prompt management tool developed by legeling. Built with Electron, React, and TypeScript, it provides a modern desktop experience across macOS, Windows, and Linux platforms.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Features and Highlights‚Äù

Comprehensive Prompt Management

Section titled ‚ÄúComprehensive Prompt Management‚Äù

PromptHub offers a complete suite for organizing your AI prompts:

  • Create, Edit, and Delete - Full CRUD operations with intuitive interface
  • Folder and Tag System - Organize prompts with hierarchical folders and customizable tags
  • Favorites - Quick access to frequently used prompts
  • Full-Text Search - Search across titles, descriptions, and content
  • Multiple View Modes - Card, Gallery, and List views for different workflows

Version Control

Section titled ‚ÄúVersion Control‚Äù

Never lose a good prompt again:

  • Automatic History - Every edit is automatically saved
  • Version Comparison - Side-by-side diff view for changes
  • Rollback Support - Restore any previous version with one click

Variable Templates

Section titled ‚ÄúVariable Templates‚Äù

Make your prompts dynamic and reusable:

When copying or testing, PromptHub prompts you to fill in the variables, making templates infinitely reusable.

Multi-Model AI Testing

Section titled ‚ÄúMulti-Model AI Testing‚Äù

Test your prompts across different AI models:

  • 18+ Providers Supported - OpenAI, Claude, Gemini, DeepSeek, Qwen, and more
  • Parallel Testing - Compare responses from multiple models simultaneously
  • Image Generation - Support for DALL-E and Stability AI
  • Result Persistence - Save test results with each prompt

Data Security and Privacy

Section titled ‚ÄúData Security and Privacy‚Äù

Your data stays yours:

  • Local-First Storage - All data stored in local SQLite database
  • Master Password Protection - Application-level security
  • Private Folders - Encrypted storage for sensitive prompts (Beta)
  • Full Backup/Restore - Export everything in .phub.gz format
  • WebDAV Sync - Optional cloud sync with services like Nextcloud

Prerequisites and Installation

Section titled ‚ÄúPrerequisites and Installation‚Äù

System Requirements

Section titled ‚ÄúSystem Requirements‚Äù

PromptHub runs on:

  • macOS - Intel and Apple Silicon (M1/M2/M3/M4)
  • Windows - x64 architecture
  • Linux - x64 (AppImage and .deb formats)

Section titled ‚ÄúDownload and Install‚Äù

Recommended Usage Scenarios

Section titled ‚ÄúRecommended Usage Scenarios‚Äù

Daily Workflow for AI Professionals

Section titled ‚ÄúDaily Workflow for AI Professionals‚Äù

  1. Open PromptHub with your master password
  2. Review favorites for quick access to common prompts
  3. Use search to find specific prompts by context

During Work:

  1. Create new prompts as you develop them
  2. Use variable templates for repetitive tasks
  3. Test prompts across models before finalizing
  4. Tag and categorize for future retrieval

End of Day:

  1. Review version history for any changes
  2. Sync to WebDAV for backup
  3. Export important prompts for sharing

Precautions and Troubleshooting

Section titled ‚ÄúPrecautions and Troubleshooting‚Äù

Common Issues

Section titled ‚ÄúCommon Issues‚Äù

Application Won‚Äôt Start on macOS:

  • Run the xattr command mentioned in installation
  • Check System Settings > Privacy & Security

Database Corruption:

  • Use the backup feature regularly
  • Keep the .phub.gz backup file safe
  • Restore from backup if needed

AI Testing Fails:

  • Verify API key is correct
  • Check API endpoint URL
  • Ensure model name matches provider‚Äôs specification

WebDAV Sync Issues:

  • Verify WebDAV URL ends with correct path
  • Test connection in settings before enabling auto-sync
  • Check firewall/proxy settings

FAQ

Section titled ‚ÄúFAQ‚Äù

Q: Is my data sent to any cloud service? A: No, all data is stored locally. WebDAV sync is optional and user-controlled.

Q: Can I share prompts with colleagues? A: Yes, export individual prompts or full backups in .phub.gz format.

Q: What happens if I forget my master password? A: Unfortunately, encrypted data cannot be recovered without the password.

Q: Does it work offline? A: The prompt management features work fully offline. Only AI testing requires internet.

Beads: A Memory Upgrade for Your AI Coding Agent

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Beads (bd) is a distributed, git-backed graph issue tracker designed specifically for AI coding agents. Created by Steve Yegge (former Google/Amazon engineer and renowned software blogger), Beads solves one of the most frustrating problems in AI-assisted development: the context window limitation.

When you start a new session with your AI coding assistant, it loses all understanding of your project goals and progress. Beads provides a persistent, structured memory that replaces messy markdown plans with a dependency-aware graph, allowing agents to handle long-horizon tasks without losing context.

Key Highlights

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Highlights‚Äù
  • Git as Database: Issues stored as JSONL in .beads/, versioned and merged like code
  • Agent-Optimized: JSON output, dependency tracking, and auto-ready task detection
  • Zero Conflict: Hash-based IDs prevent merge collisions in multi-agent workflows
  • Invisible Infrastructure: SQLite local cache with background daemon for auto-sync
  • Memory Compaction: Semantic summarization of old tasks to save context window

Prerequisites

Section titled ‚ÄúPrerequisites‚Äù

Before installing Beads, ensure you have:

  • Operating System: Linux (glibc 2.32+), macOS, or Windows 11
  • Git: Version control system (for syncing and collaboration)
  • Go 1.24+ (optional, for building from source)

Installation

Section titled ‚ÄúInstallation‚Äù

Quick Install (Recommended)

Section titled ‚ÄúQuick Install (Recommended)‚Äù

Package Managers

Section titled ‚ÄúPackage Managers‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúVerify Installation‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúConfiguration‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúStealth Mode‚Äù

Perfect for personal use on shared projects where you don‚Äôt want to affect team workflows.

Essential Commands

Section titled ‚ÄúEssential Commands‚Äù
CommandDescription
bd readyList tasks with no open blockers
bd create "Title" -p 0Create a P0 (highest priority) task
bd dep add <child> <parent>Link tasks with dependencies
bd show <id>View task details and audit trail
bd close <id>Mark a task as completed
bd syncForce immediate synchronization
bd compactSummarize old closed tasks
bd quickstartInteractive guide for AI agents
bd dep treeVisualize hierarchical relationships

Best Practices

Section titled ‚ÄúBest Practices‚Äù

1. Use Hierarchical IDs for Epics

Section titled ‚Äú1. Use Hierarchical IDs for Epics‚Äù

2. Leverage Dependency Types

Section titled ‚Äú2. Leverage Dependency Types‚Äù

Beads supports four dependency types:

  • blocks: Task A must complete before Task B
  • related: Tasks are conceptually linked
  • parent-child: Hierarchical organization
  • discovered-from: Task found while working on another

Precautions

Section titled ‚ÄúPrecautions‚Äù

Alpha Software Warning

Section titled ‚ÄúAlpha Software Warning‚Äù

Beads is currently in alpha (v0.9.x). While stable for development:

  • Avoid using in critical production systems until 1.0 release
  • Back up important data regularly
  • Report issues on GitHub

Git Dependency

Section titled ‚ÄúGit Dependency‚Äù

Beads relies entirely on Git for synchronization:

  • Ensure git push completes successfully before ending sessions
  • The ‚Äúplane has NOT landed until git push completes‚Äù

Context Window Consideration

Section titled ‚ÄúContext Window Consideration‚Äù

While Beads reduces context consumption, complex queries can still use significant tokens. Use targeted queries (bd ready) rather than full dumps.

FAQ

Section titled ‚ÄúFAQ‚Äù

Q: How is Beads different from GitHub Issues?

Section titled ‚ÄúQ: How is Beads different from GitHub Issues?‚Äù

A: Beads offers:

  • Typed dependencies with semantic meaning
  • Offline-first design with local SQLite
  • Git-native sync without external services
  • Hash-based IDs preventing multi-agent collisions
  • Agent-optimized output (JSON format)

Q: Can I use Beads offline?

Section titled ‚ÄúQ: Can I use Beads offline?‚Äù

A: Yes! All queries run against local SQLite. Sync happens via git push/pull when network is available.

Q: What about existing issue trackers?

Section titled ‚ÄúQ: What about existing issue trackers?‚Äù

A: Beads complements rather than replaces tools like Jira or GitHub Issues. Use Beads for AI agent memory and local development; sync important issues to your main tracker.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Beads represents a paradigm shift in how we think about AI coding assistants. Instead of treating them as stateless tools that forget everything between sessions, Beads gives them persistent, structured memory that grows with your project.

By leveraging Git‚Äôs familiar workflow, providing agent-optimized queries, and implementing intelligent memory compaction, Beads enables truly long-horizon task management. Whether you‚Äôre working solo or coordinating multiple AI agents, Beads ensures your coding assistants never lose track of the bigger picture.

Desktop Commander MCP: Transform Claude into Your Ultimate AI Development Partner

Desktop Commander MCP: Transform Claude into Your Ultimate AI Development Partner

Section titled ‚ÄúDesktop Commander MCP: Transform Claude into Your Ultimate AI Development Partner‚Äù

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

What if your AI assistant could not only understand your code but also execute commands, manage files, and work across your entire operating system? Desktop Commander MCP makes this possible, transforming Claude Desktop into a powerful, autonomous development partner that goes far beyond traditional IDE-focused AI tools.

Created by Eduard Ruzga (wonderwhy-er), Desktop Commander MCP is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that bridges Claude Desktop with your local system. With over thousands of weekly npm downloads and a growing community of enthusiastic developers, it‚Äôs rapidly becoming the go-to solution for developers who want AI-assisted development without the fragmentation of multiple tools.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Features and Highlights‚Äù

üöÄ Enhanced Terminal Control

Section titled ‚ÄúüöÄ Enhanced Terminal Control‚Äù

Desktop Commander provides intelligent terminal integration with:

  • Smart process detection - Automatically knows when programs are ready for input
  • Interactive session management - Maintain long-running sessions (SSH, databases, dev servers)
  • Background execution - Run commands with timeout support
  • Process control - List, monitor, and terminate processes

üìÅ Comprehensive File Operations

Section titled ‚ÄúüìÅ Comprehensive File Operations‚Äù
  • Full filesystem access with intelligent permissions
  • Native Excel support (.xlsx, .xls, .xlsm) - read, write, edit, search
  • PDF capabilities - Extract text, create from markdown, modify existing PDFs
  • Surgical code editing - Search/replace blocks for precise changes
  • Pattern-based replacements with vscode-ripgrep integration
  • URL support - Fetch content from web resources directly

üíª In-Memory Code Execution

Section titled ‚Äúüíª In-Memory Code Execution‚Äù

Execute code without saving files:

üîß Configuration Management

Section titled ‚Äúüîß Configuration Management‚Äù

Dynamic runtime configuration:

  • Blocked commands for security
  • Shell preferences (bash, zsh, PowerShell)
  • Directory access controls
  • File read/write limits

Prerequisites and Installation

Section titled ‚ÄúPrerequisites and Installation‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúSystem Requirements‚Äù
  • Node.js (v16 or higher recommended)

What is Desktop Commander MCP?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is Desktop Commander MCP?‚Äù

Desktop Commander MCP is an open-source MCP (Model Context Protocol) server created by wonderwhy-er that enables Claude to:

  • Execute terminal commands with output streaming
  • Search and manage file systems
  • Edit files with surgical precision using diff capabilities
  • Read and write Excel, PDF, and various data files
  • Run code in memory without file persistence

‚ÄúWork with code and text, run processes and automate tasks beyond typical AI editor limitations.‚Äù

Claude Code System Prompts Revealed: Inside the AI That Powers Your Coding

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Discover the Hidden Architecture Behind Anthropic‚Äôs AI Coding Assistant

The Discovery

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Discovery‚Äù

Ever wondered what makes Claude Code tick? Thanks to the open-source community, specifically the Piebald-AI/claude-code-system-prompts repository, we now have unprecedented visibility into the intricate system prompts that power one of the most popular AI coding assistants on the market.

This repository, maintained by the team behind Piebald, provides a comprehensive breakdown of all Claude Code‚Äôs various system prompts, updated with each new version. As of Claude Code v2.0.75 (December 20th, 2025), it covers 56 versions of changelog since v2.0.14.

Why Claude Code Has Multiple System Prompts

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Claude Code Has Multiple System Prompts‚Äù

Claude Code doesn‚Äôt just have one single string for its system prompt. Instead, there are multiple components working together:

Component TypeDescription
Conditional PromptsLarge portions added depending on environment and configs
Tool DescriptionsBuiltin tools like Write, Bash, and TodoWrite
Agent PromptsSeparate system prompts for Explore, Plan, and Task agents
Utility FunctionsAI-powered features like conversation compaction, CLAUDE.md generation

The result is 40+ strings that are constantly changing and moving within a very large minified JS file.

Key Prompt Categories

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Prompt Categories‚Äù

1. Main System Prompt (2,981 tokens)

Section titled ‚Äú1. Main System Prompt (2,981 tokens)‚Äù

The core system prompt defines Claude Code‚Äôs fundamental behavior:

Communication Style:

  • Responses should be ‚Äúshort and concise‚Äù for command-line display
  • Uses GitHub-flavored markdown formatted for monospace fonts
  • Avoids emojis unless explicitly requested
  • Tools are for task completion only, not user communication

Technical Approach:

  • Prioritizes technical accuracy and truthfulness
  • Provides direct, objective technical info
  • Reads files before proposing modifications
  • Avoids over-engineering and unnecessary abstractions

2. Agent Prompts

Section titled ‚Äú2. Agent Prompts‚Äù

A2UI: Google's Agent-Driven Interface Protocol That Changes Everything

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

From Text-Only Responses to Rich, Native UIs: How Google‚Äôs A2UI Protocol Enables AI Agents to Generate Interactive Interfaces

1. Introduction: Features and Highlights

Section titled ‚Äú1. Introduction: Features and Highlights‚Äù

What is A2UI?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is A2UI?‚Äù

On December 15, 2025, Google publicly launched A2UI (Agent to UI), an open-source protocol that enables AI agents to generate rich, interactive user interfaces that render natively across platforms‚Äîwithout executing arbitrary code.

Think about it: instead of an AI agent responding with just text, it can now send back a complete, interactive form, a data visualization card, or a booking confirmation interface. The magic? Your app renders these UIs using native components, maintaining your design system while benefiting from AI-generated interfaces.

Core Problem Solved

Section titled ‚ÄúCore Problem Solved‚Äù

Traditional agent interactions face a fundamental tension:

ApproachProblem
Text-only responsesLimited expressiveness, tedious back-and-forth
HTML/JavaScript in iframesSecurity risks, sandboxing complexity, no native styling
A2UI approachDeclarative JSON data + native rendering = best of both worlds

Key Features

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Features‚Äù
FeatureDescription
Security-FirstDeclarative data format (not executable code). Agents can only render pre-approved components from your catalog
LLM-FriendlyFlat component lists with ID references, easy for LLMs to generate incrementally
Framework-AgnosticWorks with React, Flutter, Angular, SwiftUI, Lit, and more
Transport-AgnosticCompatible with A2A, AG-UI, REST (experimental)
Progressive RenderingUsers see UI building in real-time as LLMs generate

  • Key Partners: CopilotKit/AG-UI (day-zero compatibility), Opal (core contributor), Gemini Enterprise

4. Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled ‚Äú4. Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting‚Äù

Important Precautions

Section titled ‚ÄúImportant Precautions‚Äù
AreaRecommendation
SecurityOnly include components in your catalog that you trust. A2UI is declarative, not executable, but your renderer implementations must be secure
VersioningA2UI is v0.8 (Public Preview). Expect breaking changes before v1.0
PerformanceFor complex UIs, consider pagination and lazy loading in your renderer
AccessibilityYour renderer is responsible for accessibility. A2UI provides structure; you provide semantics

FAQ

Section titled ‚ÄúFAQ‚Äù

Q: How is A2UI different from sending HTML?

A: A2UI sends structured JSON that describes UI components. Your app renders these using native widgets, maintaining your design system, accessibility, and security. HTML/JS requires sandboxing and can‚Äôt integrate with native styling.

Q: Can agents execute arbitrary code through A2UI?

A: No. A2UI is a declarative data format. Agents can only request components from your pre-approved catalog. Your renderer decides how to present them.

Q: Does A2UI replace MCP (Model Context Protocol)?

A: No, they‚Äôre complementary. MCP connects agents to tools and data. A2UI defines how agents describe UIs. You can use both in the same system.

Q: What about AG-UI?

A: AG-UI is the transport layer for real-time agent-UI communication. A2UI defines the payload format. They work together beautifully.

Q: Is A2UI production-ready?

A: A2UI is v0.8 (Public Preview). It‚Äôs functional but evolving. Production use should plan for specification updates.

5. Collaboration with Similar Products and Comparative Analysis

Section titled ‚Äú5. Collaboration with Similar Products and Comparative Analysis‚Äù

The Agentic UI Protocol Landscape

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Agentic UI Protocol Landscape‚Äù

In 2025, three complementary protocols have emerged as the foundation for agent-driven interfaces:

ProtocolPurposeCreatorFocus
A2UIDeclarative UI descriptionsGoogleWhat UI to render (payload)
MCPAgent-to-tool connectionsAnthropicHow agents access tools (vertical)
AG-UIReal-time agent-UI communicationCopilotKitHow UIs receive updates (transport)
A2AAgent-to-agent communicationGoogleHow agents talk to each other (horizontal)

A2UI vs MCP-UI Comparison

Section titled ‚ÄúA2UI vs MCP-UI Comparison‚Äù
AspectA2UIMCP-UI/MCP Apps
PhilosophyNative-first: ‚ÄúBlueprint‚Äù for native componentsWeb-first: HTML/JS in sandboxed iframes
RenderingApp renders using native widgetsBrowser renders sandboxed web content
StylingInherits host app stylingIsolated styling in sandbox
Security ModelComponent catalog restrictionIframe sandboxing
Cross-PlatformSame payload works on web, mobile, desktopPrimarily web-focused
Backed ByGoogleAnthropic, OpenAI

How They Work Together

Section titled ‚ÄúHow They Work Together‚Äù

Comparative Analysis with Opal

Section titled ‚ÄúComparative Analysis with Opal‚Äù

Opal (also from Google) uses A2UI as its underlying protocol:

  • Opal provides higher-level abstractions for AI mini-apps
  • A2UI provides the wire protocol for UI descriptions
  • Together they enable ‚Äúone-sentence AI apps‚Äù

When to Use What

Section titled ‚ÄúWhen to Use What‚Äù
ScenarioRecommended Protocol
Native mobile app with AI featuresA2UI + AG-UI
Web chat with rich responsesMCP Apps or A2UI
Multi-agent orchestration with UIA2UI + A2A + AG-UI
Tool-calling with data accessMCP
Cross-platform consistencyA2UI

Roadmap

Section titled ‚ÄúRoadmap‚Äù

The A2UI team has prioritized:

  1. Specification stabilization (v1.0)
  2. React renderer (official support)
  3. Jetpack Compose and SwiftUI (native mobile)
  4. REST transport (production-ready)
  5. Integration with Genkit and LangGraph

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

A2UI represents a fundamental shift in how AI agents interact with users. Instead of text-only responses or risky code execution, agents can now describe rich, interactive UIs that render natively across platforms.

Key Takeaways:

  1. A2UI is declarative - It describes UIs, not executes code
  2. Security by design - Component catalog restricts what agents can request
  3. Framework-agnostic - One agent response works across web, mobile, desktop
  4. Composable - Works alongside MCP, AG-UI, and A2A for complete agent systems

As the agentic era accelerates, protocols like A2UI will become essential infrastructure for building AI applications that feel native, secure, and responsive.

Ready to build with A2UI? Start with the official quickstart or explore the GitHub samples.
